title: 113_hr5430
content: The "Nineveh Plain Refugee Act of 2014" allows certain aliens to apply for refugee status in-country. The Secretary of State, in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security, establishes processes in certain countries for aliens to apply for refugee status in the U.S. Suspension of these processes in a foreign country can occur for up to 90 days. The Secretary of State, with consultation from the Secretary of Homeland Security, can suspend refugee status application processes in foreign countries for up to 90 days. The suspension can be extended with notification to specific congressional committees, and a report must be submitted detailing the reasons for each suspension and extension. Aliens eligible to apply for admission to the United States as a refugee using in-country processes. Aliens within specified categories can establish a well-founded fear of persecution for refugee admission by asserting a credible basis for concern. Categories are established for nationals or residents of territories controlled by the Islamic State in certain countries. Aliens provided Priority 2 processing under the refugee resettlement priority system shall not be counted against numerical limitations for fiscal years 2014 and 2015. No alien shall be denied the opportunity to apply for admission as a refugee solely based on immediate relative status or eligibility for other immigrant classifications. Each denial of refugee status must be accompanied by written reasons. The denial of refugee status for an alien must be in writing with reasons stated. Aliens previously denied refugee status can reapply under certain conditions. The protection of aliens in specific foreign countries applying for refugee status is ensured by the Secretary of State and Secretary of Homeland Security. The Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. 1157) allows for protection or immediate removal of aliens in imminent danger. SEC. 4. REPORTS. The Secretary of State, in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security, must submit a report within 120 days of the enactment of the Act to expedite processing of refugee applications for admission to the U.S. under section 207 of the Immigration and Nationality Act. This includes plans to speed up resettlement of refugees, potentially through expanding the Refugee Corps of USCIS. The Secretary of State, in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security, is required to submit an annual report to Congress within 120 days of the Act's enactment. The report should focus on expediting refugee application processing, increasing personnel for processing, enhancing background checks, and providing projections for refugee interviews in foreign countries for fiscal years 2015 and 2016. The Secretary of State, in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security, must submit an annual report to Congress within 120 days of the Act's enactment. The report should include an assessment of financial, security, and personnel considerations needed to implement the Act, the number of specified aliens and their refugee applications status, including reasons for delays exceeding 180 days.
